quiz.title: Pre-calculus: Unit 5 Quiz 3
quiz.subtitle: 5.3: Logarithmic Functions as Inverses
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Switching between exponential and logarithmic forms

questions.question: What is the logarithmic form of $2^3 = 8$?
questions.explanation: The base of the exponent (2) becomes the base of the log; the exponent (3) is the result of the log.

questions.question: Evaluate $\log_{5}(25)$.
questions.explanation: The question is: '5 raised to what power equals 25?' Since $5^2 = 25$, the answer is 2.

questions.question: What is the domain of $f(x) = \log_{b}(x)$?
questions.explanation: You cannot take the logarithm of zero or a negative number because a positive base raised to any power is always positive.

questions.question: Which of the following is the vertical asymptote of $f(x) = \log_{3}(x)$?
questions.explanation: As $x$ approaches 0 from the right, the logarithm shoots down toward $-\infty$.

questions.question: Evaluate $\log_{7}(1)$.
questions.explanation: Any base raised to the 0 power equals 1, so $\log_{b}(1) = 0$.

questions.question: If $f(x) = 10^x$, what is $f^{-1}(x)$?
questions.explanation: The inverse of an exponential function with base 10 is the common logarithm (base 10).

questions.question: Evaluate $3^{\log_{3}(7)}$.
questions.explanation: Since exponentials and logs are inverses, they 'undo' each other: $b^{\log_{b}(x)} = x$.

questions.question: Which point must lie on the graph of $f(x) = \log_{b}(x)$?
questions.explanation: Because $b^0 = 1$ is the point $(0, 1)$ for exponents, the inverse point $(1, 0)$ is always on the log graph.

questions.question: Solve for $x$: $\log_{4}(x) = 3$.
questions.explanation: Convert to exponential form: $4^3 = x$, so $x = 64$.

scoreMessages.90: Brilliant! You've mastered the logic of logarithms.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Remember: a log is just an exponent.
scoreMessages.50: Practice converting between forms to get more comfortable.
